Situation1: A family member has a significant event they want to share with everyone.
Expectation2: Write clean, maintainable, and efficient code
Situation2: The new feature is nearly ready but performance warnings appear in code reviews
Story: I sat at my desk, the soft hum of my computer blending with the distant laughter from the living room. My daughter had called earlier, her voice bubbling with excitement—my grandson had won his first art competition, and the family was gathering tonight to celebrate. I promised I’d be there, that I wouldn’t miss it for the world. But as I stared at the code on my screen, red flags blinked back at me from the review tool. The new feature was so close to completion, but performance warnings kept cropping up. My team was counting on me to fix them before tomorrow’s release. I could almost hear my manager’s voice, reminding me of the importance of clean, efficient code. My heart tugged in two directions: the warmth of my family waiting to share a special moment, and the silent, pressing demand of my work. I glanced at the clock, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in, unsure which one I could let down.
